section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: From the air came the beginning. This is the age of the True Guru's Teachings.

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Guru Nanak Dev
author.description:
Guru Nanak Dev Ji [1469 - 1539] was the first Guru of the Sikhs born in a village named Talwandi which is now called Nankana Sahib and is in Pakistan. As a child Guru Nanak spent most of his time in isolation and meditation. He slept only for a few hours, ate small quantities of food and spoke little.

One day he disappeared while having his morning bath and reappeared 3 days later and said: There is no Hindu and there is no Muslim. By saying this he meant that titles were meaningless because all of humanity is one and the light of God shines within everyone.

section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: The Shabad is the Guru, upon whom I lovingly focus my consciousness; I am the chaylaa, the disciple.

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: Speaking the Unspoken Speech, I remain unattached.

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: O Nanak, throughout the ages, the Lord of the World is my Guru.

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. translation.text: I contemplate the sermon of the Shabad, the Word of the One God.

text: ਮੈਣ ਕੇ ਦੰਤ ਕਿਉ ਖਾਈਐ ਸਾਰੁ ॥

translation.text: "With teeth of wax, how can one chew iron?

text: ਜਿਤੁ ਗਰਬੁ ਜਾਇ ਸੁ ਕਵਣੁ ਆਹਾਰੁ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: What is that food, which takes away pride?

text: ਹਿਵੈ ਕਾ ਘਰੁ ਮੰਦਰੁ ਅਗਨਿ ਪਿਰਾਹਨੁ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: How can one live in the palace, the home of snow, wearing robes of fire?

translation.text: Where is that cave, within which one may remain unshaken?

translation.text: Who should we know to be pervading here and there?

translation.text: The absolute Lord is deep within; the absolute Lord is outside us as well. The absolute Lord totally fills the three worlds.

translation.text: By practicing control over the nine gates, one attains perfect control over the Tenth Gate.

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Guru Nanak Dev
author.description:
Guru Nanak Dev Ji [1469 - 1539] was the first Guru of the Sikhs born in a village named Talwandi which is now called Nankana Sahib and is in Pakistan. As a child Guru Nanak spent most of his time in isolation and meditation. He slept only for a few hours, ate small quantities of food and spoke little.

One day he disappeared while having his morning bath and reappeared 3 days later and said: There is no Hindu and there is no Muslim. By saying this he meant that titles were meaningless because all of humanity is one and the light of God shines within everyone.

section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: There, the unstruck sound current of the absolute Lord vibrates and resounds.

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: Behold the True Lord ever-present, and merge with Him.

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

One day he disappeared while having his morning bath and reappeared 3 days later and said: There is no Hindu and there is no Muslim. By saying this he meant that titles were meaningless because all of humanity is one and the light of God shines within everyone.

section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: The True Lord is pervading and permeating each and every heart.

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.
